I'd be happy to provide you with information on the reactions and experiences of women who have used hormonal birth control. Keep in mind that every individual's experience is unique, and it's essential to consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new medication.

Hormonal birth control, such as the pill, patch, ring, or injection, can affect women in various ways. Some common reactions and experiences reported by women who have used hormonal birth control include:

1. Menstrual changes: Hormonal birth control can cause changes in menstrual cycles, such as lighter or heavier bleeding, longer or shorter periods, or even cessation of periods (amenorrhea).
2. Mood changes: Some women may experience mood swings, irritability, or anxiety due to hormonal fluctuations.
3. Breast tenderness: Hormonal changes can cause breast tenderness or swelling in some women.
4. Weight gain: Hormonal birth control can cause weight gain in some women, although this is not a universal experience.
5. Acne: Hormonal fluctuations can cause acne in some women, especially during the first few months of using hormonal birth control.
6. Headaches: Hormonal changes can cause headaches in some women.
7. Fatigue: Hormonal birth control can cause fatigue or lethargy in some women.
8. Libido changes: Hormonal birth control can affect libido, with some women experiencing increased or decreased sexual desire.
9. Spotting or breakthrough bleeding: Hormonal birth control can cause spotting or breakthrough bleeding, especially during the first few months of use.
10. Increased risk of blood clots: Hormonal birth control can increase the risk of blood clots, especially in women who smoke or have a history of blood clots.

It's essential to note that not all women will experience these reactions, and the severity of these reactions can vary greatly from person to person. If you're considering hormonal birth control, it's crucial to discuss your medical history, lifestyle, and any concerns you may have with your healthcare provider.

Remember, it's always important to weigh the benefits and risks of any medication, including hormonal birth control, and to consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new medication.

Risperidone is used to treat the symptoms of schizophrenia (a mental illness that causes disturbed or unusual thinking, loss of interest in life, and strong or inappropriate emotions) in adults and teenagers 13 years of age and older. It is also used to treat episodes of mania (frenzied, abnormally excited, or irritated mood) or mixed episodes (symptoms of mania and depression that happen together) in adults and in teenagers and children 10 years of age and older with bipolar disorder (manic depressive disorder; a disease that causes episodes of depression, episodes of mania, or both). Risperidone is in a class of medications called atypical antipsychotics. It works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain.

1. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is the sudden, unexplained death of an infant younger than one year old. Some people call SIDS "crib death" because many babies who die of SIDS are found in their cribs. 2. SIDS is the leading cause of death in children between one month and one year old. 3. Most SIDS deaths occur when babies are between two months and four months old. 4. Premature babies, boys, African Americans, and American Indian/Alaska Native infants have a higher risk of SIDS. 5. Although health care professionals don't know what causes SIDS, they do know ways to reduce the risk. These include: (1) Placing babies on their backs to sleep, even for short naps. "Tummy time" is for when babies are awake and someone is watching; (2) Using a firm sleep surface, such as a crib mattress covered with a fitted sheet; (3) Keeping soft objects and loose bedding away from sleep area; (4) Making sure babies don't get too hot. Keep the room at a comfortable temperature for an adult.

1. Mutations in the BCKDHA, BCKDHB, and DBT genes can cause maple syrup urine disease. These three genes provide instructions for making proteins that work together as a complex. This complex is essential for breaking down the amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine, which are present in many kinds of food, particularly protein-rich foods such as milk, meat, and eggs. 2. Mutations in any of these three genes reduce or eliminate the function of the protein complex, preventing the breakdown of leucine, isoleucine, and valine. As a result, these amino acids and their byproducts build up in the body. Because high levels of these substances are toxic to the brain and other organs, their accumulation leads to the serious health problems associated with maple syrup urine disease. 3. There is no cure for maple syrup urine disease. However, a special diet and sometimes medication are used to treat the disease. The patient must avoid foods high in the amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine. These foods include high-protein foods such as milk, meat, eggs, and some legumes. Medical management involves a protein-restricted diet and administration of a form of leucine called thiamine.

Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect any part of the body, but mostly affects the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, heart and lungs. It is an autoimmune disease, which means the body's immune system attacks the tissues and organs. There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, affects many parts of the body. Discoid lupus causes a rash that doesn't go away. Subacute cutaneous lupus causes sores after being out in the sun. Another type can be caused by medication. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns.  Anyone can get lupus, but women are most at risk. Lupus is also more common in African American, Hispanic, Asian and Native American women. The cause of lupus is not known. Genetics and environmental factors may play a role.  Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are  - Joint pain or swelling  - Muscle pain  - Fever with no known cause  - Fatigue  - Red rashes, often on the face (also called the "butterfly rash")  - There is no one test to diagnose lupus, and it may take months or years to make the diagnosis. There is no cure for lupus, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it.
Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder that involves progressive muscle weakness. It is one of the most common and severe forms of muscular dystrophy.

2 main types of diabetes are type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes. Type 1 diabetes usually develops in childhood or early adulthood. With type 1 diabetes, the body does not produce insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps glucose get into your cells to give them energy. Without insulin, too much glucose stays in your blood. Over time, high blood glucose can lead to serious problems with your heart, eyes, kidneys, nerves, and gums and teeth.

Nephrotic syndrome is a group of symptoms that include protein in the urine, low blood protein levels in the blood, high cholesterol levels, high triglyceride levels, and swelling. It is caused by different disorders that damage the kidneys.  The most common cause is called focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. It happens when scar tissue forms in the kidney. Other causes include diabetes, lupus, amyloidosis, and minimal change disease.  Treatment depends on the cause. It may include medicines, changes in diet, and sometimes dialysis and a kidney transplant.

Lynch syndrome is an inherited condition that causes an increased risk of developing cancer. People with this condition have a higher risk of developing colon and rectal cancer, as well as cancers of the stomach, small intestine, liver, gallbladder ducts, upper urinary tract, brain, skin, and prostate.  Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC).

1. Polymicrogyria is a congenital malformation (a problem present from birth) involving the brain.  It is a relatively rare condition.
2. In most cases the brain has already developed most of its neurons (nerve cells) at birth.  Some neurons continue to develop for a few years after birth, but most do not.  So it is unlikely that the neurons in your sons brain will grow normally.
3. However, the brain is amazingly plastic (moldable).  Even though the neurons themselves will not grow, the connections between them are modifiable.  The brain can reorganize itself to work around problems in certain areas.  This is called "plasticity".
4. So although it is unlikely that your sons neurons will grow, it is possible that his brain can reorganize itself so he can lead a normal life.  How normal depends on the severity of the condition.
5. I would suggest that you discuss your sons condition with his doctor, who can give you a better assessment of his condition and prognosis.

1. Do I need surgery for my hernia?
Most of the time, a hernia can be treated with surgery. Surgery for a hernia is usually done on an outpatient basis. Recovery time varies depending on the size of the hernia, the technique used, and whether there are any complications. Complications from inguinal hernia surgery are rare and can include general anesthesia complications, hernia recurrence, bleeding, wound infection, painful scar, and injury to internal organs.
2. What types of hernia surgeries are available?
There are several types of hernia surgeries. The most common types of hernia surgeries include laparoscopic and open surgery. Your doctor will help you decide which type of surgery is best for you.
Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive surgery done through small incisions. The surgeon uses a laparoscope, which is a thin, lighted tube with a camera attached to it. The laparoscope is inserted through one incision and the surgery is done with other small tools inserted through other small incisions.
Open surgery is done through a larger incision. Open surgery is sometimes done if the hernia is very large or if the contents of the hernia cannot be pushed back into the abdomen through a laparoscopic procedure.
3. How do I prepare for hernia surgery?
Tell your doctor about all the medicines you are taking. Include over-the-counter medications, vitamins, and other supplements. Your doctor will tell you whether you should continue taking your medications on the day of surgery. If you have diabetes or are taking aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, or any other blood thinners, your doctor will give you special instructions.
On the day of the surgery, you will likely be asked not to drink or eat anything after midnight the night before your surgery. Your doctor or nurse will let you know when to arrive at the hospital and what to bring with you.
4. What happens during hernia surgery?
You will likely be given general anesthesia for hernia surgery. General

No, earlobe creases are not a guaranteed sign of heart disease and heart attack. There are other underlying causes. Arteriosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, can be reversed if it is caused by fatty deposits in the arteries. However, once arteriosclerosis has progressed to the point where it has caused damage to the heart, such as a heart attack, the damage is irreversible. It is still important to have the creases in your earlobes checked out by a doctor to be sure that they are not a sign of heart disease.

I am sorry to hear about the diagnosis of Leigh disease in your son. At this time, EPI-743 is still in the research and development stage, and is not yet available outside of research studies. I can understand your desire for hope, but it is important to manage expectations as research studies are still in the early stages for Leigh disease. There are some studies looking at stem cell transplantation and gene therapy approaches that show promising results in animal models of Leigh disease, but more research is needed. For families facing a diagnosis of Leigh disease in a child, the most important first step is to have comprehensive genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. There are many different genetic mutations that can cause Leigh disease, and some families may be candidates for stem cell transplantation or other treatments based on the specific genetic cause of their child's disease. If you are interested in learning more about research studies for Leigh disease, I recommend talking to your son's doctor or a genetic counselor who can help you determine if your family is a candidate for any ongoing studies. I hope that this information was helpful to you. Best wishes for your family.

Aside from the fact that pacemakers are used to treat bradyarrhythmias, which are defined as a slow heart rate, or the inability of the heart to reach the required rate, there is no clear evidence that pacemakers are effective in treating the spasms themselves. 

It is important to note that there are two types of pacemakers. The first type is transcutaneous pacemakers, which are the pacemakers that are placed under the skin of the chest, and are connected to the heart by wires (leadless pacemakers are a subtype of this type). The second type are implantable pacemakers, which have a pacemaker device that is placed under the skin, and a lead that is placed inside the heart, and are connected to the heart by this lead.

In the case of spasms, a pacemaker would be ineffective, because it is designed to treat bradyarrhythmias, and not cardiac spasms. It is true that pacemakers can help prevent some types of arrhythmias, but this is only in so far as they help maintain a steady heart rate, and do not eliminate the possibility of cardiac spasms.

Therefore, the answer to your question is that pacemakers are not effective in treating cardiac spasms.

Alcohol withdrawal is potentially life threatening, and requires inpatient or outpatient hospital care, or non-institutionalized care guided by a physician experienced in managing alcohol withdrawal.

Opiate withdrawal is not life threatening but is very uncomfortable. It can be managed in either an inpatient or outpatient setting, with around-the-clock care for at least the first few days.

Benzodiazepine withdrawal, if not done in a very long time, should also be managed by a physician experienced in managing alcohol and opiate withdrawal. Benzodiazepine withdrawal can be life threatening, and can cause seizures and death.

There are no evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of withdrawal from stimulants, hallucinogens, cannabis, or cocaine. However, these withdrawals can also be life threatening, and should be managed in a hospital or similar setting with 24-hour care.

There are no evidence-based guidelines for the treatment of withdrawal from sedatives, hypnotics, or anxiolytics. However, these withdrawals can also be life threatening, and should be managed in a hospital or similar setting with 24-hour care.

Your virus infection may be the cause of your problem back. It is important to know which virus caused the infection and whether it is a common or rare virus. Some viruses stay in the blood vessels and cause inflammation and damage to the blood vessel wall. This leads to scarring and narrowing of the blood vessel. The common causes of infectious vasculitis are HBV, HCV, and HIV. Rare causes include infectious mononucleosis, syphilis, and Lyme disease. The location of the infected blood vessel determines the symptoms. If the brain infarction occurs, it can lead to headache and stroke. If the infarction occurs in the intestine, it can lead to abdominal pain. If the infarction occurs in the kidney, it can lead to high blood pressure and kidney failure. If the infarction occurs in the limb, it can lead to gangrene. The treatment depends on the cause of the infection. Antiviral medications are used to treat viral infections. Corticosteroids are used to treat all types of infectious vasculitis.

After revision THR, the functional outcome is similar to that of a primary THR.  The mean post-operative pain score at the final follow-up was 2.2 on a 10-point scale, and the mean Harris Hip Score was 87.4 points.  There were no significant differences in the mean scores between patients with an unrevised Charnley prosthesis and those with a cemented stems.  Additionally, no significant differences were observed in the mean scores between patients younger than 65 years and those 65 years and older. These findings suggest that revision THR is a safe and effective treatment for patients with a failed hip arthroplasty.  In fact, revision THR is considered a effective treatment option for patients with a failed hip arthroplasty.

It is important to understand that cross-eyed (strabismus) is a disorder of the brain and not the eye. The brain controls the movement of the eye. When the brain controls the two eyes differently, the eyes do not move together and look in different directions.

Treatment of crossed eyes requires the expertise of a physician who specializes in their treatment, including pediatric ophthalmologists and orthoptists.

First, the underlying cause of strabismus must be ad Chat Doctor.  For example, does the child suffer from farsightedness, nearsightedness, or astigmatism? These are all common causes of strabismus. Glasses will be needed to correct the child's vision.

Next, the child will undergo a series of tests to determine the extent of the problem and the proper treatment. One such test is called the cover-uncover test. During this test, the ophthalmologist or orthoptist will cover one of the child's eyes and ask him or her to look at an object. Can the child properly look at the object with the uncovered eye?

If the child suffers from strabismus, the eyes do not work together as a team. The brain shuts off the image of the eye with the strabismus and therefore the child experiences double vision. The child will be asked to look at an object with each eye. Can the child use each eye to look at the object properly?

The orthoptist will then use various exercises to help the child's eyes work together as a team. One such exercise is called pen push. The child will be asked to push a pen back and forth between his or her eyes. Another exercise is called the "blurry G." The child will be asked to look at a "blurry G" while focusing on the center of the "G."

Surgery may be required to correct strabismus. The orthoptist and/or pediatric ophthalmologist will determine whether surgery is necessary.

Finally, the child will require frequent follow-up appointments to monitor his or her progress.

1. It is not clear what is the cause of your binocular vision problems.  Binocular vision problems can be caused by many factors including but not limited to:
a. Strabismus (misaligned eyes)
b. Ametropia (different refractive power in each eye)
c. Anisometropia (different refractive power in each eye)
d. Binocular vision anomalies
e. Accommodation (failure to adjust focus from near to far and back)
f. Ocular motility (lack of coordination of eye movement)
2. Surgery can be an option to correct some of the above causes.  For example, if you have strabismus, surgery can be performed to realign your eyes.  If you have anisometropia, you can get glasses with one lens having a different refractive power than the other.  
3. However, not all causes of binocular vision problems can be corrected with surgery.  Accommodation and ocular motility problems are examples of conditions that may not be helped by surgery.
4. I suggest you see an ophthalmologist for a full evaluation, which includes a test called the cover-uncover test.  Based on your test results, your ophthalmologist can advise you on whether surgery is a good option for you and what type.

Bruxism, which is the habitual grinding or clenching of the teeth, is a common phenomenon that can occur in response to stress or anxiety. However, the jaw is a relatively stable structure that is less likely to be affected by these types of movements than other muscle groups, such as the arms or legs. Additionally, the jaw is well-suited for the types of forceful contractions associated with bruxism, as it contains a strong bony structure that can withstand these types of movements without causing significant damage. As a result, bruxism is most commonly observed in the jaw, although it can also occur in other parts of the body as well.

1. Since the pituitary is the control center for all the hormones in the body, when it is removed problems can occur with all the hormones that the pituitary either produces itself or controls.  The problems can be adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, and the list goes on.  The problems you have faced since having the pituitary removed at age 22 are numerous, as you say.  The first step is to do blood tests to see what hormones are low and then replace them.  That is the simplest solution first.  The second solution is to find out if there is a disease process going on in the pituitary that required the removal.  There are autoimmune diseases that can cause a mass in the pituitary that requires removal, but then the problem becomes one of cause and effect.  Diabetes Insipidus is not generally one of those diseases.  The third solution is to find out if there is a genetic disease that is inherited that causes a defective pituitary.  This is rare.  The fourth solution is to find out if there was a problem during birth that caused the pituitary to be damaged.  This is the most rare of all.  So, the first step is to find out what hormones are low and replace them.

100-120 is a pretty good A1C actually. The normal A1C range is about 4-6, but many diabetics are happy to be under 7. 100-120 is about as good as uncontrolled diabetes can hope for. The lower the better, but 100-120 is pretty good. 
There are still potential complications. Diabetes is a risk factor for heart disease (the leading cause of death in the US). Controlling the diabetes doesn't eliminate the risk, but it certainly reduces it. 
There are other complications that can arise from diabetes, but they are usually a result of poor control. Poor control can lead to retinopathy (damage to the retina of the eye), nephropathy (kidney damage), and neuropathy (nerve damage). These are all serious complications, but they are usually the result of poor control. 
So, as long as your friend sticks to his regimen, exercises, and eats right, he should have no problems.

1. What is the likelihood of this being a serious condition?

Most of the time, blood in the stool or vomit is not serious. Bleeding in the stomach or esophagus can be caused by things like peptic ulcers or gastritis. But sometimes it can be a sign of a more serious problem, like cancer. It's hard to know how likely it is that the blood is serious. You should always tell your doctor if you see blood in your stool or vomit. Your doctor can do tests to find out what is causing the bleeding and if it is serious.

2. What are the possible causes of blood in the stool or vomit?

Most of the time blood in the stool or vomit is caused by things like peptic ulcers or gastritis. But sometimes it can be a sign of a more serious problem, like cancer. It can also be a side effect of medication or a sign of infection in the stomach or intestines. Sometimes blood in the stool or vomit can be caused by something you ate, like blueberries or tomatoes.

1) Place traps in various areas where you have seen or suspect you may see rodents.

It is possible for a person to go from eating dinner on Saturday to having a life-threatening intestinal issue requiring the removal of 70-80% of their small intestine and part of their large intestine by Tuesday. This is possible due to the nature of the bacteria present in food. Bacteria are microorganisms that are present in everything we eat, whether it be vegetables, meats, or even drinks like juice or water. While most of these bacteria are harmless, some can cause illness. When an individual consumes a bacteria that causes illness, their immune system will respond and attempt to fight off the infection. In some cases, the immune response can cause inflammation in the small intestine, which can lead to a condition called toxic megacolon. Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the inflamed portion of the intestine becomes so dilated that the blood supply is compromised. This can result in the need for surgery to remove portions of the intestine. While this is a rare and extreme example, it highlights the importance of ensuring safe food handling practices to minimize the risk of exposure to harmful bacteria.

1. The most common cause of a curved penis is a condition called "Chordee". It is a congenital condition, where in the penis is bent during erection. This is usually treated with a procedure called "Chordee release surgery".

2. Another procedure is "Penile straightening plaster", where a plaster model of the straight penis is made, and then used to straighten the penis.

3. There is also "Penile liposculpture", where fatty tissue is removed from the base of the penis shaft, to make it straighter.

4. "Penile prosthesis" can also be used, where a semi-rigid or flexible implant is inserted in the penis to maintain an erection, which in turn will straighten the penis.

5. "Penile girth enhancement" is another method, where a hollow implant is inserted in the penis shaft, which is then filled with saline solution, to increase the girth and straighten the penis.

6. "Penile straightening surgery" is the most common method to straighten a curved penis.

No, cataracts can not be treated with LASIK surgery. LASIK (laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis) is a type of refractive surgery used to correct nearsightedness, farsightedness, and astigmatism. LASIK reshapes the cornea so that light focuses properly on the retina, reducing a person's need for glasses or contact lenses. 

Cataracts, on the other hand, are a condition in which the lens of the eye becomes cloudy, causing blurred vision. Cataracts are typically treated with surgery, in which the cloudy lens is removed and replaced with an artificial lens. The artificial lens is designed to correct the vision problems caused by the cataract. 

There is no LASIK surgery to correct cataracts, but there is LASER cataract surgery, which uses a laser to make incisions in the eye during cataract surgery. Laser cataract surgery is becoming more common, as it is more precise and can reduce some of the risks associated with cataract surgery, such as eye infections or bleeding. However, LASIK and cataract surgery are two separate procedures with different purposes, and one cannot replace the other.

1. The lungs are the organs that help us breathe. They take in oxygen and get rid of carbon dioxide. When we breathe, our diaphragm (the muscle under our lungs) moves downward and pushes our ribs outward to make room for our lungs to expand. This allows air to enter into our lungs through our nose or mouth. Once the air is inside our lungs, tiny blood vessels called capillaries surround the alveoli (air sacs). Oxygen from the air passes into the bloodstream through these capillaries. At the same time, carbon dioxide leaves the bloodstream and enters the alveoli. Then, when we exhale, the diaphragm moves upward and pulls our ribs inward, which makes room for our lungs to contract. This causes the air to be pushed out of our lungs.

Sepsis is a serious condition that can occur when the body s response to an infection damages its own tissues and organs. It is caused by bacteria or other microorganisms entering the bloodstream and causing an overwhelming immune response. While sepsis can be treated with antibiotics and other medications, it can also lead to organ failure and death if not treated promptly.

While sepsis can be caused by any type of infection, it is most commonly associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin infections. However, it can also occur as a result of surgery or other medical procedures. In some cases, sepsis may develop after a person has been admitted to the hospital for another reason. This is known as nosocomial sepsis, which means  hospital-acquired  sepsis.

Nosocomial sepsis occurs when a patient contracts an infection while in the hospital, either through contact with contaminated equipment or surfaces, or through exposure to other patients who are already infected. To prevent nosocomial sepsis, hospitals must take steps to ensure that their facilities are clean and free of harmful pathogens. They must also follow strict protocols for handling and disposing of medical waste, and they must provide staff members with proper training on infection control measures.

In addition, hospitals should have systems in place to monitor patients for signs of infection and to quickly identify and treat any potential cases of sepsis. By taking these precautions, hospitals can help reduce the risk of nosocomial sepsis and protect the health and safety of their patients.
